localizedDescriptions.en: Any health care condition which may impact on the physical, mental and/or social well-being of an individual, that may require diagnostic, therapeutic or educational action, and which has been determined by a clinician. A diagnosis is based on scientific evaluation of physical signs, symptoms, history, laboratory tests results, and procedures.

annotations.ANZACS-QI Items.Description: The term acute myocardial infarction should be used when there is evidence of myocardial necrosis in a clinical setting consistent with acute myocardial ischaemia (Third Universal Definition of Myocardial Infarction ESC/ACCF/AHA/WHF Task Froce, Circulation 2012;126:2020-2035)

localizedDescriptions.en: Identification of the problem or diagnosis. Coding of the problem or diagnosis with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

annotations.ANZACS-QI Items.Description: Type 1 - Spontaneous myocardial infarction related to ischaemia due to a primary coronary event such as plaque erosion and/or rupture, fissuring, or dissection. Type 2 - Myocardial infarction secondary to ischaemia due to either increased oxygen demand or decreased supply, e.g. coronary artery spasm, coronary embolism, anaemia, arrhythmias, hypertension, or hypotension.  Type 3 - Sudden unexpected cardiac death, including cardiac arrest, often with symptoms suggestive of myocardial ischaemia, accompanied by presumably new ST elevation, or new LBBB, or evidence of fresh thrombus in a coronary artery by angiography and/or at autopsy, but death occurring before blood samples could be obtained, or at a time before the appearance of cardiac biomarkers in the blood. Type 4a - Myocardial infarction associated with PCI. Type 4b - Myocardial infarction associated with stent thrombosis as documented by angiography or at autopsy. Type 5 - Myocardial infarction associated with CABG
annotations.ANZACS-QI Items.Notes: Only select MI Type if Type of ACS is ‘NSTEMI’ or ‘STEMI’

localizedDescriptions.en: Captures risk stratification for individuals with acute MI

The Killip classification is a system used in individuals with an acute myocardial infarction (heart attack), in order to risk stratify them. Individuals with a low Killip class are less likely to die within the first 30 days after their myocardial infarction than individuals with a high Killip class
blah
rales (crakles) up to 50% of each lung field, S3, or elevated JVP
rales (crakles) > 50% of each lung field
Shock Trial definition: BP <90 for > 30 min or inotropes to keep BP > 90

Any health care condition which may impact on the physical, mental and/or social well-being of an individual, that may require diagnostic, therapeutic or educational action, and which has been determined by a clinician. annotations.ANZACS-QI Items.Description: First heart rate recorded on arrival to hospital. Where the suspected ACS occurs late after hospital admission eg post operatively complete the GRACE risk operation items (HR, BP, Killip class etc) using the data at the time the ACS was first suspected.

localizedDescriptions.en: Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The heart rate, measured in beats per minute.

annotations.ANZACS-QI Items.Description: First heart rate recorded on arrival to hospital. Where the suspected ACS occurs late after hospital admission eg post operatively complete the GRACE risk operation items (HR, BP, Killip class etc) using the data at the time the ACS was first suspected.
annotations.comment: Run-time name constraints have been specified, in order to simplify the renaming of this data element to Pulse Rate or Heart Rate, as required.

localizedDescriptions.en: The local measurement of arterial blood pressure which is a surrogate for arterial. pressure in the systemic circulation.  Most commonly, use of the term 'blood pressure' refers to measurement of brachial artery pressure in the upper arm.
Default event
Peak systemic arterial blood pressure  - measured in systolic or contraction phase of the heart cycle.
An electrocardiograph (ECG) is an interpretation of the electrical activity of the heart over time, recorded non-invasively using external skin electrodes.
An overall interpretative comment on this recording.
An overall interpretative comment on this recording.
Multimedia representation of the ECG.
The findings and interpretation of pathology tests performed on patient-related specimens.

annotations.comment: This archetype may be used to record a single valued test, but will often be specialised or templated to represent multiple value or 'panel' tests. This archetype also acts as the parent for specialisations appropriate for more specific laboratory tests, e.g. microbiology, histopathology.

localizedDescriptions.en: Any event.
Identification of the pathology test performed, sometimes including specimen type and patient state.

annotations.comment: A test result may be for a single analyte, or a group of items, including panel tests. Coding with a terminology, potientially a pre-coordinated term including specimen type, is preferred, where possible. May be coded with LOINC or Snomed-CT. Examples include "Glucose", "Urea and Electrolytes", "Swab",  “Cortisol (am)” or "Liver Biopsy".

localizedDescriptions.en: The publication status of the entire pathology test result.
The result is complete and verified by the responsible pathologist.
A group of results.

annotations.comment: If a name or code is used, it is provided by run-time re-naming of the Results may be grouped by specimen, or by some other name or code to describe what binds all the results together. 'Result group' element or may be fixed in a specialised archetype or template. Coding with a terminology, potentially a pre-coordinated term including specimen type, is preferred where possible for the name. Should be coded with LOINC or SNOMED CT.

localizedDescriptions.en: Specific detailed result, including both the value of the result item, and additional information that may be useful for clinical interpretation.

annotations.comment: Results include whatever specific data items pathology labs report as part of the clinical service; it is not confined to measurements. The result is identified by run-time re-naming of the 'Result group' element or may be fixed in a specialised archetype or template. Coding with a terminology, potentially a pre-coordinated term including specimen type, is preferred where possible for the name. Should be coded with LOINC or SNOMED CT. Examples include: glucose, haemoglobin, phenotype, titre, or scatterplot image. If the test result is for a single analyte, then both the "Test Result Name" and the "Result" item will specify the same test.

localizedDescriptions.en: Actual value of the result.

annotations.comment: Most result values will be numerical measurements, but others may be coded concepts, free text, or multimedia images.

localizedDescriptions.en: The status of the result value.

annotations.comment: Allows a single test result to contain multiple individual results each with their own status.

localizedDescriptions.en: The result is complete and verified by the responsible pathologist.
Concise and clinically contextualised narrative interpretation of the pathology test results.

annotations.comment: This data element allows a rough indication of cigarette use to be recorded, for example a pack a day or 5-10 per day. The period of time is not specified. If exact consumption at specific points in time or averages/maximums over specified intervals of time are required, use the OBSERVATION.tobacco_use archetype.

annotations.comment: This archetype may be used to record a single valued test, but will often be specialised or templated to represent multiple value or 'panel' tests. This archetype also acts as the parent for specialisations appropriate for more specific laboratory tests, e.g. microbiology, histopathology.

localizedDescriptions.en: Any event.

annotations.comment: A test result may be for a single analyte, or a group of items, including panel tests. Coding with a terminology, potientially a pre-coordinated term including specimen type, is preferred, where possible. May be coded with LOINC or Snomed-CT. Examples include "Glucose", "Urea and Electrolytes", "Swab",  “Cortisol (am)” or "Liver Biopsy".

localizedDescriptions.en: The diagnostic service that performs the examination.

annotations.comment: For example, biochemistry, haematology. Coding with a terminology is desirable, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: The publication status of the entire pathology test result.
No result yet available.
This is an initial or interim result: data may be missing or verification not been performed.
The result is complete and verified by the responsible pathologist.
The result has been modified subsequent to being Final, and is complete and verified by the responsible pathologist.
The result is unavailable because the test was not started or not completed.
The date and/or time that the entire result was issued for the recorded ‘Overall Test result status’.
Description of clinical information available at the time of interpretation of results, which may include a link to the original clinical information provided in the test request.
A group of results.

annotations.comment: If a name or code is used, it is provided by run-time re-naming of the Results may be grouped by specimen, or by some other name or code to describe what binds all the results together. Coding with a terminology, potentially a pre-coordinated term including specimen type, is preferred where possible for the name. Should be coded with LOINC or SNOMED CT.

Coding with a terminology, potentially a pre-coordinated term including specimen type, is preferred where possible for the name. Should be coded with LOINC or SNOMED CT. Examples include: glucose, haemoglobin, phenotype, titre, or scatterplot image. The local ID assigned to the test order by the order filler, usually by the Laboratory Information System (LIS).

annotations.comment: Assigning an identifier to a request by the Radiology lnformation System enables tracking progress of the request and enables linking results to requests. It also provides a reference to assist with enquiries and it is usually equivalent to the HL7 Filler Order Identifier.

Description of clinical information available at the time of interpretation of results, which may include a link to the original clinical information provided in the test request.

annotations.comment: If a name or code is used, it is provided by run-time re-naming of the Results may be grouped by specimen, or by some other name or code to describe what binds all the results together. 'Result group' element or may be fixed in a specialised archetype or template. Coding with a terminology, potentially a pre-coordinated term including specimen type, is preferred where possible for the name. Should be coded with LOINC or SNOMED CT.

localizedDescriptions.en: Specific detailed result, including both the value of the result item, and additional information that may be useful for clinical interpretation.

annotations.comment: Results include whatever specific data items pathology labs report as part of the clinical service; it is not confined to measurements. The result is identified by run-time re-naming of the 'Result group' element or may be fixed in a specialised archetype or template. Coding with a terminology, potentially a pre-coordinated term including specimen type, is preferred where possible for the name. Should be coded with LOINC or SNOMED CT. Examples include: glucose, haemoglobin, phenotype, titre, or scatterplot image. If the test result is for a single analyte, then both the "Test Result Name" and the "Result" item will specify the same test.

localizedDescriptions.en: Actual value of the result.

annotations.comment: Most result values will be numerical measurements, but others may be coded concepts, free text, or multimedia images.

annotations.comment: May include statements about significant, unexpected or unreliable. values, or information about the source of the value where this may be relevant to the interpretation of the result.

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional advice on the applicability of the reference range.
The status of the result value.

annotations.comment: Allows a single test result to contain multiple individual results each with their own status.

localizedDescriptions.en: No result yet available.
This is an initial or interim result: data may be missing or verification not been performed.
The result is complete and verified by the responsible pathologist.
The result has been modified subsequent to being Final, and is complete and verified by the responsible pathologist.
The result is unavailable because the test was not started or not completed.
Concise and clinically contextualised narrative interpretation of the pathology test results.
Single word, phrase or brief description representing the narrative in the 'Conclusion'.

annotations.comment: Coding with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: Rich text representation of the entire result as issued by the diagnostic service.

annotations.comment: Multiple formats are allowed but they must be semantically equivalent.

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional narrative about the test not captured in other fields.
Details concerning a single pathology test requested.

annotations.comment: Usually there is one test request (or "order") for each result, however in some circumstances multiple test requests may be represented using a single Pathology test result archetype.

localizedDescriptions.en: The local ID assigned to the order by the order requester.

annotations.comment: Equivalent to the Placer Order Identifier.

localizedDescriptions.en: Identification of pathology test requested, where the test requested differs from the test actually performed.
The local ID assigned to the test order by the order filler, usually by the Laboratory Information System (LIS).

annotations.comment: Assigning an identifier to a request by the Radiology lnformation System enables tracking progress of the request and enables linking results to requests. It also provides a reference to assist with enquiries and it is usually equivalent to the HL7 Filler Order Identifier.

localizedDescriptions.en: The identifier given to the laboratory test result of a pathology investigation.
The findings and interpretation of pathology tests performed on patient-related specimens.

annotations.comment: This archetype may be used to record a single valued test, but will often be specialised or templated to represent multiple value or 'panel' tests. This archetype also acts as the parent for specialisations appropriate for more specific laboratory tests, e.g. microbiology, histopathology.

localizedDescriptions.en: Any event.
Identification of the pathology test performed, sometimes including specimen type and patient state.

annotations.comment: A test result may be for a single analyte, or a group of items, including panel tests. Coding with a terminology, potientially a pre-coordinated term including specimen type, is preferred, where possible. May be coded with LOINC or Snomed-CT. Examples include "Glucose", "Urea and Electrolytes", "Swab",  “Cortisol (am)” or "Liver Biopsy".

localizedDescriptions.en: The diagnostic service that performs the examination.

annotations.comment: For example, biochemistry, haematology. Coding with a terminology is desirable, where possible.

children.name: Is the time of onset of the most severe symptoms available?
children.localizedName: Is the time of onset of the most severe symptoms available?

localizedNames.en: Is the time of onset of the most severe symptoms available?

localizedDescriptions.en: : If more than one attack, record the most severe one. If more than one attack of equivalent severity, record the longest one. If unable to determine the time of onset based on this, investigator will decide after reviewing the case or clinical notes. Symptom will be chest pain in the majority of cases. In the absence of chest pain, record the onset of the surrogate symptom (eg breathlessness, syncope, etc.

children.name: Primary PCI to culprit lesion successful
children.localizedName: Primary PCI to culprit lesion successful

localizedNames.en: Primary PCI to culprit lesion successful

localizedDescriptions.en:
Indicate the date and time the first device was activated regardless of the type of device used. Use the earliest time from the following: 
• Time of first balloon inflation 
• Time of first stent deployment 
• Time of first treatment of lesion (thrombectomy/aspiration device, laser, rotational atherectomy) 
• If the lesion cannot be crossed with a guidewire or device (and thus none of the above apply), use the time of guidewire introduction. 
Please note that this is a process measure about the timeliness of treatment. It is NOT a clinical outcomes measure based on TIMI flow or clinical reperfusion. It does not matter whether the baseline angiogram showed TIMI 3 flow or if the final post-PCI angiogram showed TIMI 0 flow. What is being measured is the time of the first mechanical treatment of the culprit lesion, not the time when TIMI 3 flow was (or was not) restored. (2013 ACCF/AHA data elements)
A generic heading for contextual renaming within a template.
For capturing Investigations in ACS form in ANZACS-QI Registry.
Includes exercise treadmill test, exercise stress echo, dobutamine stress echo, nuclear stress study.
Left ventricular ejection fraction assessed by echo or LV angiogram or other modality on this admission.
A generic heading for contextual renaming within a template.
Record the findings and interpretation of an imaging examination, or series of examinations, performed.

Identification of the imaging examination or procedure performed, typically including modality and anatomical location (including laterality). Coding with a terminology, potientially a pre-coordinated term specifying both modality and anatomical location, is desirable where possible. Possible candidate terminologies: LOINC, SNOMED CT or RadLex.

The imaging method used to perform the examination e.g Ultrasound, CT, X-ray. Coding with a terminology is desirable, where possible. If the modality is specified by a code in the Examination result name, then this field is not required.

Specific and identified anatomical location.
Named anatomical location - ideally would be coded where possible.
The status of the examination result as a whole.
The result is complete and verified by the responsible radiologist.
Concise and clinically contextualised narrative interpretation of the imaging examination findings.

list.value: >=50% stenosis in one or more vessels
list.label: >=50% stenosis in one or more vessels

localizedDescriptions.en: A generic heading for contextual renaming within a template.
To capture invasive management details on ACS form in ANZACS-QI Registry.
LAD, RCA and Cx territories include major side branches arising from these vessels. LAD territory includes LAD and diagonal vessels. Cx territory includes CX, OM and ramus intermediate vessels.
This includes staged PCI, planned restudy, suspected new event, acute vessel closure. Record details including operator, findings, PCI details.
Displayed for 4th PCI and onwards

children.name: Medication at Discharge from Cardio/Medical Care
children.localizedName: Medication at Discharge from Cardio/Medical Care

localizedNames.en: Medication at Discharge from Cardio/Medical Care

localizedDescriptions.en: A generic heading for contextual renaming within a template.
Details of use, administration, dispensing or other care step relating to a medicine, vaccine or other therapeutic good which may arise from an instruction from a clinician.
The medicine, vaccine or other therapeutic good which was the focus of the action. This element will normally be coded with a medicines terminology but free text may be required in some cases.
Any instructions given to the subject of care or carer at the time of the action.

The reason(s) the specific action or step was carried out. Note: This is not the reason for the medication instruction, rather the specific reason e.g. for administration or for ceasing the medication.
A comment on the action taken.
The sequence number specific to the action being recorded.
A different brand of the same medicine, vaccine or other therapeutic good was substituted for the one nominated in the order.
Assigned by the manufacturer to identify the manufacturing batch of the item.
The expiry date of the medicine administered as documented by the manufacturer.
The name of the person to whom this was dispensed, if not the subject of care.
The number of times this order has been dispensed. The sum of this number minus one and the remaining repeats provides the number of repeats on the original order.

The number of times the medicine, vaccine or other therapeutic good may still be dispensed without re-issue of a prescription or order. Note: This is the information required by the subject of care and prescriber.
The category of reimbursement or subsidy sought for the item.
Statements about medications that need to be positively recorded as absent or excluded.
The statement about the absence or exclusion. Use to capture any information that is needed to be explicitly recorded as being absent or excluded within the record.
The statement about the absence or exclusion. Use to capture any information that is needed to be explicitly recorded as being absent or excluded within the record.
Not currently taking any medication.
Positive statement about medications that are explicitly not being taken or used at the time of recording.
Positive statement about medications that are explicitly known not to have ever been taken or used at the time of recording.
Identification of a treatment, medicine, vaccine or procedure which should not be administered or performed on this subject.
Identified contraindication to a treatment, medicine, vaccine or procedure.

annotations.comment: Coding of the identified Contraindication with a terminology is desirable, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: Evidence or rationale for the contraindication.

annotations.comment: This should be explicitly stated, so that this rationale can be explicit if this data is shared in a message or with another clinical system, although an optional link to evidence within the same record is also permitted.

localizedDescriptions.en: The date at which the contraindication was most recently deemed to apply, normally as a result of  clinical assertion or affirmation.
A generic heading for contextual renaming within a template.
In-hospital outcomes for use in ANZACS-QI ACS and PCI/CathLab datasets
Captures risk stratification for individuals with acute MI

The Killip classification is a system used in individuals with an acute myocardial infarction (heart attack), in order to risk stratify them. Individuals with a low Killip class are less likely to die within the first 30 days after their myocardial infarction than individuals with a high Killip class

rales (crakles) > 50% of each lung field
